Daniel, the 2:1 ratio that you describe sounds reasonable.  Ultimately, t=
hat ratio will affect the protection of innovation.  If it is too extreme, =
species will end up less protected because low-fitness species will have su=
ch a relative disadvantage. 

However, I think a more important overall poi=
nt is that the precise ratio probably doesn't matter all that much.  It is =
robust to perturbation as long as it's reasonable.  I would just stay away =
from fitness ranges like 1,000,001 to 1,000,100 or something like that.

ke=
n

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@...> wrote:
>
> Thi=
s stuff is new to me, and seems pretty important.  If you wouldn't mind,
> =
Ken, I'd appreciate a little elaboration.  I'm using the speciation strateg=
y
> of the original JNeat (completely unaltered)
> 
> If we view population=
 fitness as a distribution, what kind of mean and
> standard deviation shou=
ld we see in the population to get speciation to
> behave appropriately?  O=
r, if you prefer, what is the order of magnitude of
> the appropriate ratio=
 between the fitness of the best organism/species and
> the worst?
> 
> I'm=
 working in a domain, for example, where fitness is a simple percentage.
> =
 During the early to middle stages evolution the mean fitness might be 0.5,=

> with a standard deviation of 0.1.  The ratio between the fitness of the =
best
> guy and the worst guy is probably only about 2:1.  Is that divergent=
 enough
> to get meaningful benefit from speciation?  Or do you need someth=
ing closer
> to the 5 to 1 ratio that you cited?
> 
> Thanks,
> Daniel
> 
>=
 
> On Sun, Feb 28, 2010 at 8:08 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> 
> >
> >
>=
 >
> >
> > The way that fitness is scaled indeed has a significant effect a=
t the
> > speciation level of NEAT. Because the number of offspring that a =
species
> > will produce collectively is proportional to its average fitnes=
s (which
> > follows from fitness sharing in NEAT), scaling fitness in diff=
erent ways
> > will cause offspring to be allocated to species in different=
 proportions.
> >
> > I don't think there is a harm in exponential fitness =
if you want to
> > emphasize the curve in certain ways. The same motivation=
s that apply in
> > regulars EAs can apply to NEAT.
> >
> > However, the pl=
ace where fitness scales can hamper NEAT is if they are
> > proportionally =
too narrow. For example, if every species has an average
> > fitness betwee=
n 1001 and 1005, then they will look practically the same to
> > fitness sh=
aring and will all get roughly the same number of offspring. In
> > that ca=
se, speciation won't really distinguish much between better and worse
> > s=
pecies. However, if the average fitnesses were instead between 1 and 5,
> >=
 then the allocations would vary a lot, with many more offspring going to t=
he
> > 5 species than the 1 (because 5 is 5 times 1). This example shows th=
at the
> > range of fitnesses is not the only important consideration. It i=
s also
> > important how big the range is compared to the absolute magnitud=
e.
> >
> > ken
> >
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.=
com>, Jeff Clune <jclune@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > Thanks for this answer Ke=
n, and I apologize for the belated reply.
> > >
> > > If you don't mind, I =
would still like to try to determine whether it
> > helps
> > > to make fit=
ness functions exponential.
> > >
> > > For example, if you had an evaluati=
on that produced a score, would the
> > > following two fitness functions b=
e equivalent?
> > >
> > > Fitness =3D 2^score
> > > Fitness =3D score
> > >=

> > > Or would it be better to use the former? In many EAs (at least those=
 with
> > > fitness proportional selection or something similar), people us=
e the
> > > exponential version to magnify the difference in fitness and en=
sure that
> > > similar increases in fitness are always just as important, =
even as the
> > base
> > > fitness increases.
> > >
> > > It seems that wit=
hin a species, if truncation selection is used, it will
> > not
> > > make =
a difference. How about at the higher level allocation of how many
> > > or=
ganisms each species will get (i.e., between-species competition)?
> > >
> =
> > I know it is hard for you to give a general answer, since different NEA=
T
> > > implementations may differ in their selection schemes (at both leve=
ls?),
> > but
> > > how about for the original NEAT? I am also interested i=
n how things work
> > in
> > > Jason's HyperNEAT code, if you happen to kno=
w the answer to that. I think
> > > Jason used the original NEAT code, so t=
he answer should be the same?
> > >
> > >
> > > Best regards,
> > > Jeff Cl=
une
> > >
> > > Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> > > jclu=
ne@

tanley@>

> > > > Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.co=
m>" <
> > neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com>>
> > > > Date: Sun,=
 24 Jan 2010 00:53:27 -0000
> > > > To: "neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoo=
groups.com>" <
> > neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com>>
> > > > S=
ubject: [neat] Re: Fitness and Selection
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Da=
niel and Jeff, please note that the rules cited by Daniel in a couple
> > c=
ases
> > > > are not exactly what my implementation of NEAT does (and since=
 JNEAT is
> > based
> > > > on my own I assume it follows the same rules mi=
ne). Of course the code
> > is a
> > > > bit complicated and figuring out w=
hat it does is difficult to do
> > quickly. In
> > > > particular here are =
corrections for b and c:
> > > >
> > > > (b) Species are not killed off if =
their average fitness falls below a
> > certain
> > > > level. Rather, ther=
e is a rule that, if turned on, would kill off a
> > species
> > > > if its=
 maximum fitness has not improved in some number of generations.
> > That
>=
 > > > is a way to dump stagnant species.
> > > >
> > > > (c) "Stolen babie=
s" is almost never used in any experiment that I have
> > seen
> > > > publ=
ished or published myself, so it isn't really an important
> > mechanism.
>=
 > > > However, it is a way to increase greediness. As Daniel rightly infer=
s,
> > it
> > > > doesn't steal actual genetic code from one species, but r=
ather it
> > steals the
> > > > *right* to reproduce from the worse species=
 and redistributes that
> > right to
> > > > the better ones. So sort of Ro=
bin Hood in reverse (steal from the poor
> > to
> > > > help the rich).
> >=
 > >
> > > > In terms of "weighting the number of offspring produced toward=
s the
> > stronger
> > > > species," that is correct, but that is just a pr=
operty of fitness
> > sharing,
> > > > which NEAT uses.
> > > >
> > > > In =
general, the most important selection mechanism in NEAT is in fact
> > fitn=
ess
> > > > sharing, which makes it difficult for good species to take over=
 the
> > entire
> > > > population because individuals must share the fitne=
ss of their species.
> > So as
> > > > a species gets bigger, the fitness o=
f everyone within it drops. I would
> > > > consider fitness sharing essent=
ial to NEAT's "identity."
> > > >
> > > > However, all fitness sharing does=
 is adjust the fitnesses of everyone
> > in the
> > > > population. So afte=
r that, there is still a need to decide how many
> > > > offpspring individ=
uals get. It is at this point that versions of NEAT
> > may
> > > > diverge=
 and I do not have a strong opinion because I do not consider
> > the
> > >=
 > choice essential to NEAT's identity.
> > > >
> > > > In my own implement=
ations, first, offspring numbers are assigned on a
> > > > per-species basi=
s (proportionally to *adjusted* fitness after fitness
> > sharing)
> > > > =
and then they are assigned within to species to individuals. My version
> >=
 of
> > > > NEAT usually uses truncation selection within species. So it ju=
st cuts
> > out
> > > > the bottom n% of the species from being eligible to=
 reproduce and the
> > rest get
> > > > to reproduce. (rtNEAT is different =
of course since it only produces one
> > at a
> > > > time - it probabilist=
ic). The remaining individuals are selected as
> > parents
> > > > randomly=
.
> > > >
> > > > Perhaps most appealing for me about this approach is the =
idea that each
> > > > species can be treated as its own little mini-popula=
tion in which
> > whatever
> > > > selection scheme you choose is implement=
ed. I think it makes conceptual
> > sense
> > > > to think of a species as =
a population because *within* a species one
> > wants the
> > > > same kind=
 of healthy phenomena to happen that one wants in a regular GA
> > with a
>=
 > > > full population.
> > > >
> > > > Of course, you could alternatively =
choose roulette wheel selection
> > within
> > > > species (after adjusting=
 fitness for fitness sharing) or something
> > else. That
> > > > choice is=
 not that important, and I have tried a number of schemes and
> > found
> >=
 > > that, at least with NEAT, it makes limited difference which one is
> >=
 chosen.
> > > > But the fitness sharing is still key.
> > > >
> > > > So J=
eff, there is no simple to answer to "what kind of selection scheme
> > doe=
s
> > > > NEAT use" because it is a multi-level scheme that first acts at t=
he
> > level of
> > > > speciation and then at the level of individuals wit=
hin species. So no
> > one
> > > > blanket terms really covers the whole th=
ing. To distill it to a short
> > phrase,
> > > > perhaps we could say it u=
ses "fitness sharing and any other scheme
> > after
> > > > fitness-sharing=
."
> > > >
> > > > ken
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >

yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com>, Daniel Tuohy
> > <danielr2e@> wro=
te:

> > > >> I'm helping with the overhaul of JNeat. I hadn't even=
 looked at
> > selection,

 Perhaps Ken could explain
> > what is
> > > >> going on here.
> > > >>
> >=
 > >> It looks like all the selection pressure comes from:
> > > >>
> > > >=
> (a) Elitism within species ("champions" are automatically cloned into
> >=
 the
> > > >> subsequent generation)
> > > >> (b) Killing off species when =
their average fitness falls below a
> > certain
> > > >> threshhold
> > > >=
> (c) Weighting the number of offspring produced towards the stronger
> > >=
 >> species. (In the code the metaphor of "stealing babies" from weaker
> >=
 species
> > > >> is used, although this doesn't seem quite right to me. Su=
rely if a
> > species
> > > >> were to "steal a baby", it would retain the =
genetic material of it's
> > > >> original species?)
> > > >>
> > > >> With=
 all that said, you're question is on the mathematical function
> > that
> =
> > >> describes selection pressure relative to fitness, right?
> > Unfortu=
nately, I'm
> > > >> finding it very difficult to infer that from the above=
 mechanisms. I
> > bet
> > > >> Ken knows :)
> > > >>
> > > >> Daniel
